etymologies: mid 17th century; earliest use found in Joseph Hall (1574–1656), bishop of Norwich, religious writer, and satirist. From post-classical Latin praeservat-, past participial stem of praeservare preserve + -ory, perhaps after conservatory

definitions: Preservative; intended to preserve or protect.
A place in which people, things, etc., are protected or preserved.
A room for storing perishable foodstuffs at a low temperature; an apparatus for preserving perishable foodstuffs; (also) a factory for the preparation of preserved foodstuffs. Now chiefly historical.
